texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most of the recent Fedora upgrades have been quite smooth. There were definitely some rough spots back in Fedora 15 and Fedora 17 with the
texts.text: Most of the recent Fedora upgrades have been quite smooth. There were definitely some rough spots back in Fedora 15 and Fedora 17 with the

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: migration and the switch to systemd. The upgrade from Fedora 23 to Fedora 24 has been really easy except for one minor quirk: my two and three finger taps don't seem to work on the touchpad.
texts.text: migration and the switch to systemd. The upgrade from Fedora 23 to Fedora 24 has been really easy except for one minor quirk: my two and three finger taps don't seem to work on the touchpad.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I use a  Lenovo ThinkPad X1 Carbon (3rd gen)  and it has a clickpad along with physical buttons across the top. I use the two finger taps (to do a secondary click) frequently. After the Fedora 24 upgrade, I can still do  clicks  with one, two or three fingers, but the  taps  don't work.
texts.text: I use a  Lenovo ThinkPad X1 Carbon (3rd gen)  and it has a clickpad along with physical buttons across the top. I use the two finger taps (to do a secondary click) frequently. After the Fedora 24 upgrade, I can still do  clicks  with one, two or three fingers, but the  taps  don't work.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , I began to narrow down the problem:
texts.text: , I began to narrow down the problem:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[major@arsenic ~]$ xinput list
⎡ Virtual core pointer                      id=2    [master pointer  (3)]
⎜   ↳ Virtual core XTEST pointer                id=4    [slave  pointer  (2)]
⎜   ↳ SynPS/2 Synaptics TouchPad                id=11   [slave  pointer  (2)]
⎜   ↳ TPPS/2 IBM TrackPoint                     id=12   [slave  pointer  (2)]
⎣ Virtual core keyboard                     id=3    [master keyboard (2)]
    ↳ Virtual core XTEST keyboard               id=5    [slave  keyboard (3)]
    ↳ Power Button                              id=6    [slave  keyboard (3)]
    ↳ Video Bus                                 id=7    [slave  keyboard (3)]
    ↳ Sleep Button                              id=8    [slave  keyboard (3)]
    ↳ Integrated Camera                         id=9    [slave  keyboard (3)]
    ↳ AT Translated Set 2 keyboard              id=10   [slave  keyboard (3)]
    ↳ ThinkPad Extra Buttons                    id=13   [slave  keyboard (3)]
[major@arsenic ~]$ xinput list-props 11 | grep Tap
    Synaptics Tap Time (271):   180
    Synaptics Tap Move (272):   252
    Synaptics Tap Durations (273):  180, 100, 100
    Synaptics Tap Action (285): 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0
texts.text:
[major@arsenic ~]$ xinput list
⎡ Virtual core pointer                      id=2    [master pointer  (3)]
⎜   ↳ Virtual core XTEST pointer                id=4    [slave  pointer  (2)]
⎜   ↳ SynPS/2 Synaptics TouchPad                id=11   [slave  pointer  (2)]
⎜   ↳ TPPS/2 IBM TrackPoint                     id=12   [slave  pointer  (2)]
⎣ Virtual core keyboard                     id=3    [master keyboard (2)]
    ↳ Virtual core XTEST keyboard               id=5    [slave  keyboard (3)]
    ↳ Power Button                              id=6    [slave  keyboard (3)]
    ↳ Video Bus                                 id=7    [slave  keyboard (3)]
    ↳ Sleep Button                              id=8    [slave  keyboard (3)]
    ↳ Integrated Camera                         id=9    [slave  keyboard (3)]
    ↳ AT Translated Set 2 keyboard              id=10   [slave  keyboard (3)]
    ↳ ThinkPad Extra Buttons                    id=13   [slave  keyboard (3)]
[major@arsenic ~]$ xinput list-props 11 | grep Tap
    Synaptics Tap Time (271):   180
    Synaptics Tap Move (272):   252
    Synaptics Tap Durations (273):  180, 100, 100
    Synaptics Tap Action (285): 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: is what I need to adjust. What do those numbers mean, anyway?
texts.text: is what I need to adjust. What do those numbers mean, anyway?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After some searching, I found the answer in some  Synaptics documentation :
texts.text: After some searching, I found the answer in some  Synaptics documentation :

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
Synaptics Tap Action
8 bit, up to MAX_TAP values (see synaptics.h), 0 disables an element. order: RT, RB, LT, LB, F1, F2, F3.
texts.text:
Synaptics Tap Action
8 bit, up to MAX_TAP values (see synaptics.h), 0 disables an element. order: RT, RB, LT, LB, F1, F2, F3.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This seems like what I want, but what do those abbreviations mean at the end? I scrolled up on the page and found something useful:
texts.text: This seems like what I want, but what do those abbreviations mean at the end? I scrolled up on the page and found something useful:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
Option "RTCornerButton" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a right top corner tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"
Option "RBCornerButton" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a right bottom corner tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"
Option "LTCornerButton" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a left top corner tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"
Option "LBCornerButton" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a left bottom corner tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"
Option "TapButton1" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a non-corner one-finger tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"
Option "TapButton2" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a non-corner two-finger tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"
Option "TapButton3" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a non-corner three-finger tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"
texts.text:
Option "RTCornerButton" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a right top corner tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"
Option "RBCornerButton" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a right bottom corner tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"
Option "LTCornerButton" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a left top corner tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"
Option "LBCornerButton" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a left bottom corner tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"
Option "TapButton1" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a non-corner one-finger tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"
Option "TapButton2" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a non-corner two-finger tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"
Option "TapButton3" "integer"
Which mouse button is reported on a non-corner three-finger tap. Set to 0 to disable. Property: "Synaptics Tap Action"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The last three are the ones I care about. Then the abbreviations made sense:
texts.text: The last three are the ones I care about. Then the abbreviations made sense:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: setting was already set to  1 , which means a primary tap. I need
texts.text: setting was already set to  1 , which means a primary tap. I need

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: set to  3  (two fingers for a secondary button tap) and
texts.text: set to  3  (two fingers for a secondary button tap) and

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: set to  2  (three fingers for a middle button tap). Let's try with
texts.text: set to  2  (three fingers for a middle button tap). Let's try with

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: SUCCESS!  The secondary and middle taps have returned!
texts.text: SUCCESS!  The secondary and middle taps have returned!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's make the setting permanent. You could add this to a
texts.text: Let's make the setting permanent. You could add this to a

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: or some other file that the display manager runs, but this isn't helpful if you have a touchpad that could be removed or re-added (like a USB touchpad). For this, we need an extra X configuration file.
texts.text: or some other file that the display manager runs, but this isn't helpful if you have a touchpad that could be removed or re-added (like a USB touchpad). For this, we need an extra X configuration file.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
Section "InputClass"
       Identifier "tap-by-default"
       MatchIsTouchpad "on"
       Option "TapButton1" "1"
       Option "TapButton2" "3"
       Option "TapButton3" "2"
EndSection
texts.text:
Section "InputClass"
       Identifier "tap-by-default"
       MatchIsTouchpad "on"
       Option "TapButton1" "1"
       Option "TapButton2" "3"
       Option "TapButton3" "2"
EndSection

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The configuration file specifies what we want to occur when one, two or three fingers tap on the pad. We're also being careful here to match only on touchpads to avoid tinkering with a mouse or other pointer device.
texts.text: The configuration file specifies what we want to occur when one, two or three fingers tap on the pad. We're also being careful here to match only on touchpads to avoid tinkering with a mouse or other pointer device.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Log out of your X session and log in again. Your two and three finger taps should still be working!
texts.text: Log out of your X session and log in again. Your two and three finger taps should still be working!
